concepts.technical_definition: An extinct order of herbivorous therapsids that lived from the Permian to Late Triassic periods, characterized by turtle-like beaks and typically two large upper canine teeth (tusks)
concepts.accessible_definition: An extinct group of plant-eating mammal-like reptiles that lived 270-200 million years ago, known for their distinctive turtle-like beaks and tusks
concepts.context_usage: The main taxonomic group being studied - all specimens belong to this order

concepts.technical_definition: A major clade within Dicynodontia that includes the most diverse and widespread dicynodonts of the Triassic period, typically large-bodied forms
concepts.accessible_definition: A major evolutionary group of dicynodonts that became very successful during the Triassic period, including many large species
concepts.context_usage: The specific group that the new species Woznikella belongs to

concepts.technical_definition: A family of large kannemeyeriiform dicynodonts from the Middle to Late Triassic, characterized by specific cranial and postcranial features
concepts.accessible_definition: A family of large dicynodonts that lived during the middle to late Triassic period, representing some of the most advanced forms
concepts.context_usage: The family that Woznikella is most closely related to based on anatomical features

concepts.technical_definition: A major group of synapsids that includes the ancestors of mammals, characterized by specific skull features and more advanced metabolic capabilities
concepts.accessible_definition: A group of ancient reptiles that were the ancestors of mammals, with more advanced features than earlier reptiles
concepts.context_usage: The broader evolutionary group that dicynodonts belong to

concepts.technical_definition: A major group of amniotes distinguished by having a single temporal fenestra (opening) in the skull behind each eye socket
concepts.accessible_definition: A major group of vertebrate animals that includes mammals and their extinct relatives, identified by a specific skull opening
concepts.context_usage: The highest taxonomic level discussed in the paper's classification scheme

concepts.technical_definition: A unique derived character state that is found only in a single terminal taxon and serves to distinguish it from all other taxa
concepts.accessible_definition: A unique evolutionary characteristic that is found only in one species and helps distinguish it from all other species
concepts.context_usage: Used to describe the unique anterodorsally directed acromion that distinguishes Woznikella from all other dicynodonts

concepts.technical_definition: A shared derived character state that is present in two or more taxa and their common ancestor but not in more distantly related taxa
concepts.accessible_definition: A shared evolutionary characteristic that indicates two or more species descended from a common ancestor
concepts.context_usage: Used to identify evolutionary relationships between different dicynodont species

concepts.technical_definition: A method for reconstructing evolutionary relationships among organisms using shared derived characteristics and computational algorithms
concepts.accessible_definition: A scientific method for determining how different species are related to each other through evolution
concepts.context_usage: The primary method used to determine where Woznikella fits in the dicynodont family tree

concepts.technical_definition: A method of phylogenetic analysis that groups organisms based on shared derived characteristics and constructs branching diagrams called cladograms
concepts.accessible_definition: A way of organizing species into family trees based on shared evolutionary characteristics
concepts.context_usage: The analytical framework used to understand dicynodont relationships

concepts.technical_definition: A data structure used in phylogenetic analysis where rows represent taxa and columns represent morphological or molecular characters with different states
concepts.accessible_definition: A data table that organizes anatomical features of different species to compare their evolutionary relationships
concepts.context_usage: The dataset of 199 characters used to analyze dicynodont relationships

concepts.technical_definition: A statistical resampling technique used to assess the reliability of phylogenetic tree branches by measuring support values
concepts.accessible_definition: A statistical method for testing how confident we can be in different parts of an evolutionary family tree
concepts.context_usage: Used to test the reliability of the phylogenetic relationships found in the analysis

concepts.technical_definition: A phylogenetic tree that summarizes the common branching patterns found across multiple equally parsimonious trees
concepts.accessible_definition: A family tree that represents the most agreed-upon relationships when multiple possible trees are found
concepts.context_usage: The final tree used for biogeographic analysis after resolving conflicting phylogenetic signals

concepts.technical_definition: The study of the geographic distribution of organisms and the historical processes that have shaped these distributions
concepts.accessible_definition: The study of where different species live around the world and how they got there through geological time
concepts.context_usage: Used to understand how dicynodonts spread across the ancient supercontinent Pangea

concepts.technical_definition: A phylogenetic method for inferring the characteristics of extinct common ancestors based on the traits of their descendants
concepts.accessible_definition: A method for figuring out what extinct ancestor species were like based on their living or fossilized descendants
concepts.context_usage: Used to determine where different dicynodont groups originally lived before spreading to other continents

concepts.technical_definition: The shoulder blade bone that forms part of the pectoral girdle and provides attachment sites for limb muscles
concepts.accessible_definition: The shoulder blade bone that connects to muscles controlling the front leg
concepts.context_usage: The most distinctive bone of Woznikella, with unique shape and acromion orientation

concepts.technical_definition: A bony process projecting from the scapula that serves as an attachment point for shoulder muscles
concepts.accessible_definition: A bony projection from the shoulder blade where shoulder muscles attach
concepts.context_usage: The part of the scapula that has unique anterodorsal orientation in Woznikella

concepts.technical_definition: A paired bone forming the anterior part of the upper jaw and snout in vertebrates
concepts.accessible_definition: The bone that forms the front tip of the upper jaw and snout
concepts.context_usage: Shows diagnostic triradiate ridge pattern in Woznikella

concepts.technical_definition: Having three radiating branches or projections from a central point
concepts.accessible_definition: Having three branches that spread out from a central point, like a three-pointed star
concepts.context_usage: Describes the distinctive three-branched ridge pattern on Woznikella's premaxilla

concepts.technical_definition: The tooth-bearing bone of the lower jaw in vertebrates
concepts.accessible_definition: The main bone of the lower jaw that would normally hold teeth
concepts.context_usage: Part of the mandible preserved in Woznikella, showing specific ridge patterns

concepts.technical_definition: The dorsal portion of a vertebra that surrounds and protects the spinal cord
concepts.accessible_definition: The upper part of a backbone bone that forms a protective arch over the spinal cord
concepts.context_usage: Multiple neural arches preserved in Woznikella specimen

concepts.technical_definition: The main body of a vertebra, typically cylindrical and bearing the weight-bearing function
concepts.accessible_definition: The main round body of a backbone bone that bears the animal's weight
concepts.context_usage: Several vertebral centra preserved in Woznikella specimen

concepts.technical_definition: The first stage of the Late Triassic period, approximately 237-227 million years ago
concepts.accessible_definition: A time period about 230 million years ago during the late Triassic when dinosaurs were first appearing
concepts.context_usage: The geological age when Woznikella lived in Poland

concepts.technical_definition: The middle stage of the Late Triassic period, approximately 227-208 million years ago
concepts.accessible_definition: A time period about 215 million years ago during the late Triassic
concepts.context_usage: Possible alternative age for some of the Polish dicynodont localities

concepts.technical_definition: The final stage of the Late Triassic period, approximately 208-201 million years ago
concepts.accessible_definition: The last time period of the Triassic, about 205 million years ago, just before the major extinction event
concepts.context_usage: The latest possible age for some dicynodont occurrences before their extinction

concepts.technical_definition: The supercontinent that existed during the late Paleozoic and early Mesozoic eras, before breaking apart into the modern continents
concepts.accessible_definition: The ancient supercontinent when all of today's continents were joined together as one giant landmass
concepts.context_usage: The geographic context for understanding dicynodont distribution and migration patterns

concepts.technical_definition: The movement of organisms from their area of origin to new geographic areas, leading to range expansion
concepts.accessible_definition: The process by which animals spread from their original home to new areas
concepts.context_usage: The primary mechanism explaining how dicynodonts spread from Africa to other continents

concepts.technical_definition: The geographic separation of populations due to the formation of barriers such as mountain ranges or seas
concepts.accessible_definition: When populations of animals get separated by geographic barriers like mountains or oceans
concepts.context_usage: An alternative explanation for dicynodont distribution patterns

concepts.technical_definition: A region with exceptionally high biodiversity or evolutionary activity
concepts.accessible_definition: An area where many different species live or where lots of evolution happens
concepts.context_usage: Southeastern Africa identified as the main center of dicynodont diversity and evolution

concepts.technical_definition: The biogeographic region including modern-day South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Malawi, Zambia, and Tanzania
concepts.accessible_definition: The southern and eastern parts of the African continent
concepts.context_usage: Identified as the primary center of dicynodont evolution and diversity

concepts.technical_definition: The study of the form and structure of organisms, including their external appearance and internal anatomy
concepts.accessible_definition: The study of the shape, size, and structure of living things
concepts.context_usage: The primary type of data used to identify and classify dicynodont species

concepts.technical_definition: The study of what happens to organisms after death, including decay, burial, and fossilization processes
concepts.accessible_definition: The study of how dead organisms become fossils and what happens to them during that process
concepts.context_usage: Used to explain the different preservation states of bones on different sides of the Woznikella specimen

concepts.technical_definition: The single specimen designated as the name-bearing type of a species for taxonomic purposes
concepts.accessible_definition: The official reference specimen that defines what a species looks like
concepts.context_usage: ZPAL V. 34/1 is designated as the holotype of Woznikella triradiata

concepts.technical_definition: The development of an individual organism from embryo to adult, including growth and maturation changes
concepts.accessible_definition: The process of how an individual animal grows and develops from baby to adult
concepts.context_usage: Used to explain some of the anatomical features seen in the Woznikella specimen

concepts.technical_definition: Two evolutionary lineages that are each other's closest relatives, sharing an immediate common ancestor
concepts.accessible_definition: Two species or groups that are most closely related to each other in the evolutionary family tree
concepts.context_usage: Used to describe evolutionary relationships between different dicynodont groups

concepts.technical_definition: A group of organisms that includes a common ancestor and all of its descendants
concepts.accessible_definition: A natural evolutionary group that includes an ancestor species and all species that descended from it
concepts.context_usage: Used to evaluate whether taxonomic groups represent natural evolutionary units

concepts.technical_definition: All parts of the skeleton excluding the skull, including the vertebral column, ribs, and limb bones
concepts.accessible_definition: All the bones in the body except for the skull - the backbone, ribs, and leg bones
concepts.context_usage: Important source of diagnostic features for Woznikella, especially the distinctive scapula

concepts.technical_definition: A natural opening or hole in a bone, often for the passage of nerves or blood vessels
concepts.accessible_definition: A natural hole in a bone where nerves or blood vessels pass through
concepts.context_usage: Various foramina mentioned in anatomical descriptions of Woznikella bones

concepts.technical_definition: The joint between two bones, especially in the skull, where bones meet and often fuse during development
concepts.accessible_definition: The place where two bones meet and join together, especially in the skull
concepts.context_usage: Used to describe how different skull bones connect in Woznikella

concepts.technical_definition: A principle in phylogenetic analysis that favors the evolutionary tree requiring the fewest number of character changes
concepts.accessible_definition: The idea that the simplest evolutionary explanation requiring the fewest changes is usually the best
concepts.context_usage: The method used to select the best phylogenetic trees from the analysis
